---
title: "Good and Bad Procrastination, Speed Matters, Sunk Cost Fallacy, & More"
date: 2025-07-02
draft: false
---

<p id="">Welcome to the new friends of the Mental Models, Concepts, and Frameworks newsletter who have joined us since last week!</p><h1 id="">This Week: 12 mental models you can use daily to improve your life</h1><h2 id="">Good and Bad Procrastination</h2><p id="">Good procrastination is avoiding work with 0 chance of being mentioned in your obituary—like errands.</p><p id="">”Unless you're working on the biggest things you could be, you're type-B procrastinating, no matter how much you're getting done.”</p><p id="">h/t <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..HNrCfSRtGOhH6O75E_LjoXgna7z7CEyCT3qCV65BjEE" target="_blank" id="">@paulg</a></p><h2 id="">Decomplication</h2><p id="">We’ve been led to believe that our everyday problems—weight loss, productivity, saving money—require complex solutions.</p><p id="">This is called ‘artificial complexity.’</p><p id="">Decomplication is the process of boiling problems down to their simplest form.</p><p id="">h/t <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..Dq9KHpcyGIpPC15P__IZEKpVgb5l4WpgOtAcj6W-PpM" target="_blank" id="">@nateliason</a></p><figure class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fa75800ffb445c38627e1_image.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">Speed Matters</h2><p id="">The faster you do things, the less activation energy is required to do any one thing.</p><p id="">To avoid procrastination, keep the activation energy low by shortening the timeframe for the work that needs to be done, and work faster.</p><p id="">h/t <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..iwSWSskMiwl2PyGlrlErM4Av_e8aO8R6xiwWZdwZhv4" target="_blank" id="">@jsomers</a></p><figure class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fa758c5c8a47c7849906a_image.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">Sunk Cost Fallacy</h2><p id="">You irrationally cling to things that have already cost you something and use valuable mental energy doing so:</p><ul id=""><li id="">Projects</li><li id="">Investments</li><li id="">Relationships</li></ul><p id="">To escape, ask yourself:</p><ul id=""><li id="">Had I not already invested in this, would I do so today?</li></ul><p id="">Cut the sunk costs.</p><h2 id="">Consider Unintended Consequences</h2><p id="">Before making a decision, ask, "What are the possible unplanned outcomes that could occur?"</p><p id="">Focus on the possible second-order effects—can you live with ALL of them?</p><p id="">“We make choices, but we don't always choose the consequences.”</p><p id="">—<a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..RRRUcSQ3O1M6JtQRSRsFkshw3H3NwA7BDS6ZIqMmEFk" target="_blank" id="">Sean Covey</a></p><h2 id="">Via Negativa</h2><p id="">When we have a problem, our natural instinct is to add a new habit or buy a solution.</p><p id="">But usually, you improve your life by subtracting instead.</p><p id="">The foods you avoid are more important than the foods you eat.</p><p id="">Subtracting distractions is the key to productivity.</p><h2 id=""><a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..9GsY0_qAOhdPqfVHB3kLwpAdQ9xV0KbKooaSkhCE2T4" target="_blank" id="">Help This Person</a></h2><p id="">Every time you encounter another person, think: "How can I help this person?"</p><p id="">It's not altruistic.</p><p id="">Nothing else can so quickly accelerate your career and quality of life.</p><p id="">Helpful people don't ask "how can I help?"</p><p id="">They just help.</p><p id=""><strong id="">Tip from a Proven Ghostwriter - Help This Person — Givers Deliver</strong></p><p id="">Bruce Kasanoff’s career guide, How to Self-Promote (Without Being a Jerk), says anytime you interact with another person, three words should be in your mind: help this person.</p><p id="">giversdeliver.org</p><h2 id=""><a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..1RWnxYyXtRmIu9d_2Ttsq4mFY4WrXWDTZIO1k-EESv0" target="_blank" id="">Reversible vs. Irreversible Decisions Framework</a></h2><p id="">Irreversible decisions are 'one-way doors.'</p><p id="">They must be made slowly and deliberately.</p><p id="">Reversible decisions are 'two-way doors.'</p><p id="">These decisions can and should be made quickly.</p><h2 id="">Pre-Mortem</h2><p id="">Involves assuming that your decision has failed and working backwards to determine what the potential causes were.</p><p id="">This process has multiple benefits:</p><p id="">• Removes overconfidence and irrational optimism</p><p id="">• Reveals blind spots</p><p id="">• Simplifies thinking</p><p id="">h/t <a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..UwCDk48WAek9VRkae7WIyQ4gV878wN64lPUnH7_ZOvA" target="_blank" id="">@KleInsight</a></p><figure class="w-richtext-figure-type-image w-richtext-align-center" data-rt-type="image" data-rt-align="center"><div><img src="https://uploads-ssl.webflow.com/63fd511e232de229bfe66c52/640fa75800ffb45f528627e0_image.jpeg" id="" width="auto" height="auto" loading="auto"></div></figure><h2 id="">10/10/10 Rule</h2><p id="">We're all guilty of making decisions without thinking about long term consequences.</p><p id="">To avoid this, ask:</p><p id="">How will I feel about this 10 minutes from now?</p><p id="">10 months from now?</p><p id="">10 years from now?</p><p id="">This helps clarify the decision that results in a win/win/win.</p><h2 id="">Think for Yourself</h2><p id="">Thinking for yourself is life’s greatest competitive advantage—you see opportunities others don’t.</p><p id="">How?</p><ul id=""><li id="">Read History</li><li id="">Ask, “Is it true?”</li><li id="">Meet different types of people</li><li id="">Be less aware of conventional beliefs</li><li id="">Cultivate independent-minded friends</li></ul><h2 id=""><a href="https://flight.beehiiv.net/v2/clicks/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..qITIaxgCh3sCZp7Ev1asaFtCPcfjkEQfJ7GOPHN_fN0" target="_blank" id="">The World-Class Framework</a></h2><p id="">How you do anything is how you do everything.</p><p id="">Your personal brand is the sum of the thousands of micro-acts you put in over the course of your career or life.</p><p id="">It’s hard to find meaning in menial or boring tasks.</p><p id="">There’s often no immediate payoff that comes with them—like any good habit, there’s no immediate gratification.</p><p id="">We just want to get them done as quickly as possible so we can get on with the real, more interesting work.</p><p id="">But, this is a mistake.</p><p id="">Because how you do anything is how you do everything.</p><p id="">Your personal brand is the summation of the thousands of micro-acts you put in over the course of your career or life.</p><p id="">It’s what you do when no one is looking or expecting you to do a great job.</p><p id="">And the surest way in life to find luck is to make sure you give your very best in each and every one of those moments.</p><p id="">Because you never know what might be around the corner.</p><p id="">And you never know when doing your best will lead to a life-changing opportunity.</p><p id="">Remember:</p><p id="">Every day, you’re not just working for someone else.</p><p id="">You’re working for your future self.</p><p id="">You’re your own boss—the boss of the ‘luck’ that will eventually come your way.</p><p id="">Make the choice to increase your luck by being ‘world-class’ in everything you do.</p><h1 id="">That's it, I hope you enjoyed reading :)</h1><h3 id="">How are you finding these newsletters?</h3><ul id=""><li id=""><a href="https://alexbrogan.beehiiv.com/login" target="_blank" id="">Awesome, keep em' coming!</a></li><li id=""><a href="https://alexbrogan.beehiiv.com/login" target="_blank" id="">They're okay</a></li><li id=""><a href="https://alexbrogan.beehiiv.com/login" target="_blank" id="">Make them better!</a></li></ul><p>‍</p>
